data.title: Transition metalâ€“free ketene formation from carbon monoxide through isolable ketenyl anions

paragraphs.context: Ketenyl anions are generated from the reaction of metalated ylides with carbon monoxide (CO), leading to the formation of ketenes and related compounds. These anions exhibit an electronic structure between that of a ketenyl anion and ethynolate, but also have enhanced stability, making them valuable reagents in organic synthesis. The ketenyl anions react selectively with a range of electrophiles at the carbon atom, offering high-yielding and versatile access to ketenes and related compounds.

qas.question: What is used to generate ketenyl anions?
What type of structure do ketenyl anions exhibit?

answers.text: Between that of a ketenyl anion and ethynolate

qas.question: Why are ketenyl anions considered valuable in organic synthesis?
Do ketenyl anions react selectively with electrophiles at the oxygen atom?
What compounds can be accessed through the reaction of ketenyl anions?
How does the electronic structure of ketenyl anions contribute to their reactivity?

answers.text: It results in a reduced amphiphilicity

qas.question: Is the protonation of ketenyl anions thermodynamically favored at the oxygen atom?
What is the outcome of treating ketenyl anions with primary chlorophosphines?
Can ketenyl anions be synthesized directly from stable ylides?
What new reactivity pattern is demonstrated by the reaction of ketenyl anions with diphenylsulfide?
